Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Elucidating the genomic signature of mate competition in a pipefish using a population genomics approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study aims to understand how adult behavior can determine which genes are passed from parents to offspring and how these processes vary among populations within a species. These goals will be addressed by comparing the natural genetic variation in adults and their offspring within a single population of pipefish. This study will also quantify genetic variation in multiple populations across a broad geographic range, which will provide data regarding how reproductive patterns vary among populations. The focal organism is the straight-nosed pipefish, Nerophis ophidion, which is found in Sweden, and the project takes advantage of recent advances in DNA sequencing technology to analyze the genetic variation at the scale of the entire genome. This species is of interest because females compete intensely for access to mates and the males provide all care for the developing offspring.

This project addresses a major subject in biology and genetics, namely how behaviors at different stages during the life cycle affect how genes are passed on from one generation to the next. Additionally, the analytical approach of comparing genetic variation between adults and offspring using new sequencing technologies is a novel combination of a mathematical model from the 1970's and new statistical methods. This approach could have broad applications in many fields and for many species, including as a diagnostic tool for understanding what pressures are affecting threatened and endangered species and for understanding multi-generational effects of human diseases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Competition between mates can result in strong selection pressure and result in the rapid evolution of flashy traits. This strong selection on the traits involved in mate competition and mate choice changes the frequency of genetic variants in the genetic regions associated with the traits, leaving a signature of selection. In this project, we set out to characterize these signatures of selection in pipefish and seahorses, marine fishes with male pregnancy. In these species, males provide all of the parental care. Seahorses mate monogamously (they only have one mate), so the competition for mates is not particularly intense. In the pipefish species we focused on in this study (the Gulf pipefish and the straightnosed pipefish) the females mate with multiple males and have flashy, iridescent patterns on their bodies that they use to compete for access to males (see Figure 1).

              In this project, we set out to compare genomic signatures of selection in two distantly-related species of pipefish that have similar mating systems and similar female traits. From previous projects, we had next-generation sequencing data for twelve populations of Gulf pipefish from throughout the Gulf of Mexico, and those populations show a pattern of isolation-by-distance, where genetic distance is highly correlated with geographic distance, and we found some genetic loci that were associated with the female trait used in mate competition. In this project, we collected similar data from the straightnosed pipefish. Straightnosed pipefish differ from Gulf pipefish in the sense that the populations throughout the Baltic Sea do not show a large degree of differentiation.

              We also collected genomic data from the dwarf seahorse to compare genomic differences (including the distribution of hormone receptors throughout the genome) in this monogamous species to the multiply-mating Gulf pipefish. The Gulf pipefish genome was recently published, facilitating this analysis. Finally, we investigated the genomic basis of the trait involved in mate choice in the Gulf pipefish using RNA-sequencing of the skin of females, where the trait is, as compared to males.

              These projects provided us with several broader impacts opportunities. First, we trained students from different backgrounds (including two other countries). Additionally, we interacted with the public and participated in outreach events throughout the duration of the award, giving a total of six talks to schools and clubs. Finally, we continued to maintain our citizen science group, Pipefish World, and used the research from this award as examples of ongoing research in the annual newsletters to Pipefish World contributors.

 


Last Modified: 06/22/2017
Modified by: Sarah P Flanagan

Image
  • Females of the two species of pipefish focused on in this study. The top is the Gulf pipefish (found in the Gulf of Mexico), with iridescent bands running vertically along the body. The bottom is the straightnose pipefish (found in the Baltic Sea) with blue iridescent patterns on the female's face.
    Sarah Flanagan
    Creative Commons
    Sarah P Flanagan
    Figure 1.

In the pipefish species we focused on in this study (the Gulf pipefish and the straightnosed pipefish) the females mate with multiple males and have flashy, iridescent patterns on their bodies that they use to compete for access to males (see Figure 1).
